G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 (as applicable to custody and parenting time), G.L. c. 209, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the general equity powers of the Probate and Family Court.

G.L. c. 209.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 (as applicable to custody and parenting time), G.L. c. 209, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the general equity powers of the Probate and Family Court.

G.L. c. 209C, \u0000\u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 (as applicable to custody and parenting time), G.L. c. 209, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the general equity powers of the Probate and Family Court.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 (as applicable to custody and parenting time), G.L. c. 209, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the general equity powers of the Probate and Family Court.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns custody standards and the need for explicit findings about domestic violence in a G.L. c. 209C paternity/custody action, but it does not discuss, cite, or analyze the Probate and Family Court’s continuing jurisdiction or its general equity powers under G.L. c. 208, § 28, c. 209, or c. 209C, § 20. The case is about the adequacy of findings and the impact of domestic violence on custody determinations, not about the source or scope of the court’s ongoing jurisdiction. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific jurisdictional proposition claimed.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 (as applicable to custody and parenting time), G.L. c. 209, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the general equity powers of the Probate and Family Court.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Kali concerns standards for initial and modified custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) and § 20, and related best-interests analysis. It does not address, even in passing, the Probate and Family Court’s continuing jurisdiction over a matter under G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, or its general equity powers. Because jurisdiction and continuing jurisdiction are not discussed, the case does not provide authority for the proposition cited.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 209C, § 20, gives the Probate Court jurisdiction to modify an existing judgment for support, custody, or visitation. Such a modification should be made only if “a substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child has occurred.” Id.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Barnstable Probate and Family Court because the prior Judgment was entered in this Court and the Father resides within this county.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Barnstable Probate and Family Court because the prior Judgment was entered in this Court and the Father resides within this county.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Since entry of the 2019 Judgment, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances relating to the Child’s living, schooling, and transportation arrangements, which materially affects her welfare.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 544\u2.proposition: Since entry of the 2019 Judgment, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances relating to the Child’s living, schooling, and transportation arrangements, which materially affects her welfare.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 544\u2.support_reasoning: The cited portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurrence about statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the relocation rights of a sole legal parent before paternity is adjudicated. It does not discuss standards for modification of an existing judgment, nor what constitutes a “substantial and material change in circumstances” regarding a child’s living, schooling, or transportation affecting welfare. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about post‑judgment changed circumstances affecting a child’s welfare.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 544\u2.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. … Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286, 293\u20.proposition: Since entry of the 2019 Judgment, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances relating to the Child’s living, schooling, and transportation arrangements, which materially affects her welfare.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286, 293\u20.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a substantial and material change in circumstances regarding a child’s living, schooling, and transportation arrangements affecting the child’s welfare. Pierce v. Pierce is an alimony-modification case involving two emancipated children and addresses only changes in the former spouses’ financial and retirement circumstances. It does not involve child custody, parenting plans, or any issues about a child’s residence, schooling, transportation, or welfare, so it cannot serve as authority for the claimed proposition.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286, 293\u20.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.” Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). Here, Rudolph was successful in modifying the divorce judgment with respect to his alimony obligation, but he did not succeed in terminating that obligation.

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 370\u.proposition: The current midweek overnight arrangement—given the Father’s relocation and the resulting length of the commute—was not and could not reasonably have been contemplated at the time of the 2019 Judgment, when both parties resided within minutes of the Child’s school.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 370\u.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether a post-judgment parenting-time/overnight arrangement involving a much longer commute was or could have been contemplated at the time of an earlier custody judgment. Schuler v. Schuler deals exclusively with modification of alimony and child support based on alleged changes in the payor’s financial circumstances, not with parenting schedules, relocation, or commuting burdens. Nothing in the opinion addresses foreseeability of changes in physical custody or visitation logistics, so it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 370\u.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment… In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. Resolution of the issue rests in the judge’s sound discretion.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The extended round-trip driving on the midweek overnight, the extremely early wake-up time, and the associated fatigue are detrimental to the Child’s welfare and contrary to her best interests.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–06 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The extended round-trip driving on the midweek overnight, the extremely early wake-up time, and the associated fatigue are detrimental to the Child’s welfare and contrary to her best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody, visitation, and the best interests standard in general, but it does not address any facts about extended round-trip driving on a midweek overnight, early wake-up times, or fatigue. The only visitation discussion relates to reducing the father’s time and briefly mentions issues like substandard personal hygiene, not transportation burdens or schedules. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about detriment from midweek travel and associated fatigue.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “We pause merely to touch upon the husband’s claim that the judge ‘cut back so severely on the amount of time that [he] may spend with his children that it now is impossible for him to maintain a meaningful relationship with them.’ There is no error. From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order….”

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 243–44 (2000)
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.proposition: The Child’s need for adequate, consistent sleep on school nights, reasonable commuting time, and stability in her educational environment are central to her best interests.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.support_reasoning: The opinion does reference the child’s late bedtime and resulting tiredness affecting her ability to get to day care, but it does not articulate any broader legal principle that adequate, consistent sleep, reasonable commuting time, and educational stability are ‘central’ to best interests. Those issues appear only as factual criticisms of the mother’s parenting, not as a doctrinal statement or central holding. The court’s legal discussion of best interests is framed much more generally and does not single out sleep schedules, commuting time, or educational stability as core best-inter-interest factors.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.relevant_excerpt: “The child had earlier attended a day care program near the mother’s home in New Bedford which was paid for by welfare vouchers. Although the child was frequently absent from the program (due, the judge found, to the ‘probability that both [m]other and child were too tired [from late bedtimes] to get ready for school in the morning’), the child enjoyed the interaction and stimulation that she received in day care and benefited from it.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 262–63 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: These circumstances are materially different from those that existed when the 2019 Judgment was entered, and they justify a modification of the parenting time schedule to eliminate the midweek overnight and adjust the weekend schedule in a manner that fosters the Child’s relationship with Father while protecting her educational and physical well-being.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modifying a parenting-time schedule (eliminating a midweek overnight and adjusting weekends) based on materially different circumstances to protect a child’s education and physical well-being while fostering the relationship with the father. Rosenthal v. Maney addresses a much different issue: the standard for modifying physical custody and the legal distinction between a removal/relocation request and a custody modification, requiring a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move itself. It does not discuss fine‑tuning parenting-time schedules or endorse eliminating specific overnights on educational or physical-well-being grounds, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’ Tolos v. Tolos, 11 Mass. App. Ct. 708, 710-711 (1981).”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 900 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: These circumstances are materially different from those that existed when the 2019 Judgment was entered, and they justify a modification of the parenting time schedule to eliminate the midweek overnight and adjust the weekend schedule in a manner that fosters the Child’s relationship with Father while protecting her educational and physical well-being.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case deals with standards for an initial custody determination and the requirement that custody decisions be based on the child’s welfare and explicit findings on relevant factors. It does not address modification of an existing parenting-time schedule, material and substantial change in circumstances, or elimination/adjustment of specific overnights to protect educational and physical well-being. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority that materially changed circumstances justify modifying a parenting schedule in the specific way described.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.… The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The proposed modification is limited, targeted, and directly responsive to the material change in circumstances: it does not seek to alter the award of primary physical custody to Mother or to eliminate Father’s substantial parenting time; instead, it aims to restructure parenting time to avoid excessively burdensome school-night travel while preserving regular and meaningful contact with Father.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a limited, targeted modification of parenting time that keeps primary physical custody unchanged and preserves substantial, regular contact with the noncustodial parent while addressing burdensome school-night travel. Yannas, by contrast, addresses an initial divorce judgment granting physical custody to the mother and authorizing international relocation, with a significantly restructured visitation schedule involving long blocks of time abroad. The opinion does not discuss or endorse the type of narrow, travel-related adjustment to an existing parenting schedule described in the proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The judge…granted each parent ‘joint legal custody’ of the minor children and the wife ‘physical possession of the minor children.’ He further allowed her to remove the children to the Republic of Greece. He gave the husband the right to take the children for six weeks each summer, for one week at Christmas time, and for one week each spring, with the cost of transportation to be shared equally.”

Schuler, 382 Mass. at 370\u201372.proposition: A material change in a parent’s residence and the consequential effect on a child’s schedule, schooling, and well-being can constitute a material and substantial change sufficient to warrant modification.

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 871–72 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: A material change in a parent’s residence and the consequential effect on a child’s schedule, schooling, and well-being can constitute a material and substantial change sufficient to warrant modification.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal (relocation) request under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and the Yannas "real advantage" framework, not a modification proceeding based on a change of residence affecting schedule, schooling, and well-being. While the court acknowledges that the mother’s remarriage and proposed move are a "material and substantial change" for purposes of G.L. c. 208, § 28, it does so only to correct the trial judge’s error and then applies the removal standards, not a general rule that any such move and its impact on schooling/schedule constitutes a material change warranting modification. The case thus does not establish the broader proposition that a change in residence and its downstream effects, by themselves, constitute the type of material and substantial change sufficient to warrant modification of custody or parenting time.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce. The judge’s contrary treatment contributed to his devaluation of the mother’s marriage as a factor to be considered, and may well have had a significant effect on his over-all treatment of the case.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: Where an existing parenting plan, as applied to new circumstances, causes excessive travel, disrupted sleep, or diminished school performance for a young child, the Court has both the authority and the responsibility to adjust that plan to better serve the child’s best interests.
